awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the 6th Biennial Women-in-Theory Workshop at Harvard University in June 2018. The intended audience of the workshop is graduate students in the field of theoretical computer science (TCS). Motivated by the low overall number of female faculty members, researchers, and students in TCS world wide, the workshop has two goals. The first is to deliver an invigorating educational program to the student participants by inviting leading female researchers to present tutorials of their research topics. The second is to provide an outstanding opportunity to bring together women students from different institutions across the country and internationally, so as to foster a sense of kinship and camaraderie, and to provide access to role models in this area by having senior and junior faculty members and industrial researchers present.  

The format of this workshop consists of technical tutorials, a non-technical talk, a student rump session, and a panel discussion, following the model of the first five workshops in this series. The first five Women-in-Theory workshops were greeted with great enthusiasm both from the participants and from the TCS research community at large. Since the first workshop in 2008, the organizers have received overwhelmingly positive feedback and many participants have matured to be successful researchers. These serve as testimonials that the workshop is accomplishing its primary goal of helping women become more successful in TCS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project provided partial funding to support the 6th Biennial Women-in-Theory workshop held at Harvard University. The PI Madhu Sudan was the chair of the local arrangements for this workshop.  The scientific program committee consisted of Tal Rabin (IBM Research), Shubhangi Saraf (Rutgers University) and Lisa Zhang (Bell Laboratories, Nokia) who have been running this workshop series since its founding. 

The workshop was held at Harvard University from June 19 to June 22, 2018. The goal of the workshop was twofold: First, to deliver an invigorating educational program that enables young researchers to learn about state of the art research in computer science theory. The second goal was to bring together theory women students from different institutions and foster a sense of kinship and camaraderie. 

A record breaking 75 women students participated in the workshop. These students were selected from among another record breaking 130 applications (with almost all being first time applicants). The applications came in response to a call for participation that was circulated widely by emails and webposts on theory blogs. 79 students were selected from these 130 applications and invited to participate and 75 eventually participated making the 2018 WIT the largest WIT event till then. 

Invited speakers from CS theory included Barna Saha (U. Mass), Nancy Lynch (MIT), Julia Kempe (NYU), Bonnie Berger (MIT), Gillat Kol (Princeton), Yael Kalai (Microsoft), and Alina Ene (Boston U.) Special events included playback theatre (all students participated) with hosts Omer Reingold and Nir Shavit; a lecture on gender and bias by Anisha Asundi (Harvard), and a panel focussing on research in industry (with speakers from Google, IBM and Lincoln Labs). 

Funding from NSF was supplemented by funds from Harvard University, and industry and professional societies. Residual funds from WIT 2018 were transferred to WIT 2022.
